title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds over two dozen independent agencies in Title V, which manage federal property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. The report focuses on funding for these agencies, along with general provisions in Title VII and Cuba sanctions in Title I. Additionally, the bill funds the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, and judiciary. The FSGG appropriations bill funds various agencies in Title V, including those managing federal property and overseeing financial institutions. It also funds the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. Financial regulation issues are occasionally addressed in additional titles, but many financial regulatory agencies are funded outside of the appropriations process. The FSGG appropriations bill funds various agencies, including those managing federal property and overseeing financial institutions. The bill has been in its current form since the 2007 reorganization of the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations. The House and Senate FSGG bills fund the same agencies, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC), which is funded through the Agriculture appropriations bill in the House. President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies. President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies, with $330 million allocated for the CFTC. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is an independent regulatory agency overseeing derivatives markets, futures exchanges, swaps markets, and industry personnel. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission oversees futures exchanges, swaps markets, industry personnel, fraud prevention, and investor protection. Congressional jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees due to the market's historical ties to agriculture. Appropriations for the CFTC fall under the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee in the House and the Financial Services and General Government. Following the financial crisis of 2008, reforms in the Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction. This act also expanded CFTC oversight to include futures and options markets. The Dodd-Frank Act expanded CFTC oversight to include swaps markets with an estimated $240 trillion notional value in the US, in addition to the $34 trillion notional value of futures and options markets. The CPSC is a federal agency focused on reducing consumer product risks through safety standards, recalls, and consumer education. The CPSC monitors product recalls, educates consumers about hazards, conducts safety research, and collaborates with governments. The Trump Administration requested $123 million for the commission in FY2018, $3 million less than FY2017. This reduction included cuts to the VGBPSA grant program. The CPSC's budget for FY2018 reflects proposed adjustments, including $1.3 million less for the VGBPSA grant program and $1.7 million less for salaries and expenses due to a loss of 22 full-time employees. The budget request is divided among four strategic goals: developing an effective workforce, preventing unsafe products, responding to emerging hazards, and coordinating recall efforts. The CPSC's budget for FY2018 includes $31.3 million for field research on potential hazards and recall efforts, $8.1 million for communication on safety matters. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 provided $126 million for the CPSC. Section 502 would have halted the finalization of a rule on blade saw injuries. The FLRA is an independent federal agency that administers and enforces Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, known as the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS). This statute gives federal employees the right to join or form a union, bargain collectively over employment terms, and excludes specific agencies. Employees have the right not to join a union representing their bargaining unit. Certain agencies are excluded by law, with the President having the authority to exclude others for national security reasons. Excluded agencies include the FBI, CIA, GAO, NSA, TVA, FLRA, FSIP, and Secret Service. H.R. 3280 had provisions to tighten U.S. economic sanctions on Cuba, but they were not included in P.L. 115-141. Section 130 aimed to prohibit the importation of rum and tobacco products confiscated by the Cuban government. The provision in the current text aims to prohibit the importation of rum and tobacco products confiscated by the Cuban government. It is related to a trademark sanction on Cuba, preventing the use of funds for authorizing licenses for marks, trade names, or commercial names. The provision in the current text aims to prohibit the use of funds for authorizing licenses for marks, trade names, or commercial names that are substantially similar to those confiscated by the Cuban government, unless the original owner consents. This relates to a dispute over the Havana Club trademark between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited. In January 2016, OFAC issued a specific license for a Cuban company to renew the Havana Club trademark, which was subsequently renewed by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office until 2026. This provision was not included in the final appropriations measure for FY2017.
